author: yoavw
content:
Sorry I missed this.

> IMO, it's absolutely not the case that AA is held back by contracts attempting to discriminate against accounts with code...
> 
> can you provide examples of code in the wild to support the idea that HASCODE will hold AA back?

I don't have a comprehensive list but AA wallet devs complain about it a lot and showed me such projects before.  A quick search for modifiers like `noContractAllowed` and other common variations yields many results. Here's one: https://etherscan.io/address/0xc21D353FF4ee73C572425697f4F5aaD2109fe35b#code (many functions protected by `noContractAllowed` which is implemented like this: `require(!address(msg.sender).isContract() && msg.sender == tx.origin, "Sorry we do not accept contract!");`, and `isContract` is `assembly { size := extcodesize(account) }`.  If you want more examples we can ask AA wallets to make a list.

> the main obstacle for AA adoption is the assumption that accounts can produce ECDSA signatures, and the lack of adoption of ERC-1271 (and ERC-6492!)

The input we got from AA wallets is that the two biggest obstacles are code checks (extcodesize, tx.origin) and ERC-1271 support.  The latter has been improving a lot since https://eip1271.io/ started shaming projects into supporting it.  The "red list" used to be much longer than the green. Now it's much shorter. But code checks remain a problem.

> the only things i can think of have been NFT drops that try to prevent accounts from claiming more than one token or whatever

I think the real reason many NFT projects do this is not to prevent double-claiming but to prevent wrapping as a way to bypass royalties.  You can transfer ownership of a contract that owns an NFT but you can't do it with an EOA because the original owner will still have the key.  That's a practice we should discourage, as it goes against any form of AA.  Key rotation is a core feature.

author: frangio_
content: thanks <@727296082484265073> i'll take a look at this example and look for similar ones
